english_deep_dive.evolution_story: Originated in 19th-century America from chewing tobacco. If you bit off a 'plug' of tobacco too large to chew comfortably, you'd have to spit it out, looking foolish.
english_deep_dive.trivia: The French equivalent literally translates to 'Having eyes bigger than the stomach'.

fr.definition: Qui semble vrai mais qui est faux ; trompeur.
fr.example_sentence: L'argument spécieux de l'avocat semblait convaincant mais s'est effondré à l'examen.

english_deep_dive.evolution_story: From Latin 'speciosus' (beautiful/fair). Originally meant 'beautiful' in English too, but evolved to mean 'deceptively attractive' (looking good but bad inside) by the 17th century.
english_deep_dive.trivia: Often used in politics to describe 'specious claims' (e.g., election fraud theories that look detailed but have no proof).

en.definition: Excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters.
en.example_sentence: The garrulous old man bored us with stories about his cats.

hi.definition: Bekaar ki baaton par bahut jyada bolne wala.
hi.example_sentence: Bakwadi boodhe aadmi ne apni billiyon ki kahaniyon se humein pakka diya.

fr.definition: Excessivement loquace, surtout sur des sujets futiles.
fr.example_sentence: Le vieil homme bavard nous a ennuyés avec des histoires sur ses chats.

english_deep_dive.evolution_story: From Latin 'garrire' (to chatter/prattle). Unlike 'loquacious' (which can be eloquent), 'garrulous' almost always implies rambling, annoying, or trivial speech.
english_deep_dive.trivia: Often describes older people in literature ('garrulous veteran'), implying a loss of filter.

en.definition: Extremely happy and excited.
en.example_sentence: She was on cloud nine after getting the promotion.

hi.definition: Bahut jyada khush aur utsahi.
hi.example_sentence: Promotion milne ke baad wo saatvein aasman par thi.

fr.definition: Extrêmement heureux et excité (Être au septième ciel).
fr.example_sentence: Elle était sur un petit nuage après avoir obtenu sa promotion.

english_deep_dive.evolution_story: Often attributed to the US Weather Bureau's 1950s classification of clouds, where 'Cloud Nine' (Cumulonimbus) rises the highest (up to 40,000 ft).
english_deep_dive.trivia: Another theory links it to Buddhism's 'Cloud 9' stage of enlightenment, but the weather origin is more widely accepted for the idiom.
